segments.text: And Barbados, British West Indies.
Donald Ouellette, interviewing Art Shields, January 1st, 1983, in New York City.
Mr. Shields, when and where were you born?
Well, I just told you.
Maybe it wasn't recorded.
Barbados, British West Indies, October 31, 19...
Yes.
And when did you immigrate to the United States?
Well, I didn't immigrate.
My parents were American citizens.
We moved to another island, and I came to the States in 93.
When was the first time that you became interested in journalism?
That again is gone into quite fully in the book.
I was working as a full-time reporter for several months in 1909 on a little daily paper
in a steel town in Ohio, Dover, Ohio, a U.S. steel town.
And then the paper folded and I went back to college.
That's all in the book.
I have a whole chapter in that first year, first journalism
When did you become involved with the Daily Worker?
Well, when it started in 1924.
And what was your position then?
Reporter.
And what was your beat?
Well, the beat was a very small staff.
The beat was all Chicago.
In your earlier years, you knew John Reed?
Well, I say I told you before I met him.
Oh, no, that wasn't recorded.
I met him and talked with him, but I knew his work better than I knew him personally.
I heard him speak quite a number of times and, of course, read what he wrote.
starting in Seattle, even before that.
No, I began reading John Reed in 1913, his article in the Masses on the Silk Strike in Paterson, New Jersey.
It's a fascinating
It can be found in a book called The Education of John Reed, which is a compilation of a lot of these articles published by International.
And I heard him lecture two or three times before the World War.
And, of course, I read the masses and read his articles.
He was one of the editors.
When did you know Big Bill Hayward?
Well, yes, I knew Bill, I wouldn't say intimately, but I met him several times and went to his meetings.
I have a chapter about him, or partially about him, in the book.
It's on this Patterson Silk Strike of the IWW in 1913.
I was a reporter in New York, not on labor.
I was covering crime then.
But in my free time, because of my interest, I would run over to Patterson during the strike.
And I heard him speak.
Well, I heard him speak at other times also.
He was a tremendous speaker, a tremendous figure.
Did you know, were you associated in any way with, say, the Molly Maguires?
Well, the Molly Maguires, you'll flatter me, I'm not quite that old.
Did you know Mother Jones?
I knew Mother, I once had a two-hour talk with Mother Jones, a luncheon, and of course I followed her work closely, yes.
Incidentally, Philip Foner will have a book on Mother Jones coming out, The Historian, I suppose you know the name, in four or five months, maybe earlier.
It's a 900-page book.
He's collected everything that Mother Jones has said that was recorded.
And...
Excuse me.
When you were with the Daily Worker, or in the 19-teens, what was your politics then?
And where?
Before the war.
Before the war?
Yes.
What was your personal politics?
Before the First World War?
Yes, sir.
Well, before the First World War, I was left with a...
I was particularly interested in the IWW, but I didn't join it until just after the war.
How long were you a member in the IWW?
Probably three or four years.
How did you first become interested in maritime labor?
What were your first contacts with the scene?
I was very much interested in labor, per se, and particularly labor in the major industries, and I would say probably most actively since 1916.
I have a chapter in my book about a trip I took in 1916 on a British freighter through the submarine zone to England, and I would say that my interest was much more active after that trip.
Did you ever know Andrew Fursweth?
I've heard him speak.
I didn't know him personally, no.
Of course, when I heard him speak, I heard him speak at an American Federation of Labor convention in Atlantic City in 1925.
He had become somewhat of a figure of the past.
You see, Furiseth did very good work in his day for
the men on the deck for seamen.
He was essentially a craft unionist and he played quite a part.
He came out of the old sailing ships.
He played quite a part in organizing the sailors union of the Pacific.
Later his union tried to expand and took the
title of the ISU, the International Seaman's Union.
But I think the old man rather lost control then because there were departments for the engine men and for the stewards and they were led by conservatives and
It didn't reflect much credit on him to be connected with, but he himself was a very honest man.
What you'd call a good man, I'd say.
Senator La Follette once, the elder La Follette, in the speech, paid a great tribute to Furiseth.
He gives Furiseth credit for the first real
protective laws for seamen, the seamen's protection, I think it was called the Seamen's Act or something like that.
La Follette helped himself put it through in consultation with yours.
That was much earlier.
I don't remember the date anymore.
Yes.
But that could be looked up.
But his weakness, in a way, was partly due to the fact that he was not really an industrial unionist.
And industrial unionism is the thing.
To fight against these great corporations controlled by bankers, the old-fashioned craft union of separate unions for the different skills,
with many of the workers having very little skill, is obsolete, you see.
As a young man, what made you want to become involved and become socially aware?
Well, I had a lot of experience working, and if you work
and go through the hardships.
And you see how helpless a worker is against a giant corporation.
For instance, I worked for U.S. Steel in this little town where I finally got a job on the newspaper.
And I worked for other big corporations.
You want to do something about it.
And if you're a sympathetic person,
You enjoy the society of the men you're working with.
Their anger and their sufferings impinge on you, too.
I mean, the natural reaction is to do something about it and get together and struggle.
You said that you...
ideologically adhered to the Wobblies, the IWW, up until a couple of years after World War I?
Well, it was a slow development there.
From the Wobblies, where did you politically move to?
You see, the labor movement was weak in those days, and I was feeling my way.
There.
There wasn't too much guidance.
And ideologically, which way were you moving?
What's that?
Which way were you moving?
From the Wobblies, you ideologically moved where?
Next?
Well, I say the Wobblies were industrial unionists.
Perhaps you'd better have something to eat, if you're thinking.
The Wobblies were industrial unionists, you see.
That's what attracted me.
They had some weaknesses too, of course, which is one reason why they didn't survive.
But they were great fighters in their day.
From the Wobblies, where did you move on to next?
What?
From the Wobblies, where did you move to next ideologically?
I would say, as far as labor is concerned, somewhat broader, realizing that the Wobblies cannot do it all by themselves, that they're also, even in the craft unions, there were many good fighters.
There were also bureaucrats and
and some traders, but there were many good fighters in the ranks.
And also, in the craft unions, there was developing a move towards unity between them.
And in others, broadly speaking, it was a movement towards industrialization, towards industrial unionism.
William J.
Foster played a big part in that.
He did a tremendous job, which you're probably familiar with,
in organizing the packinghouse workers.
Do you know about that?
Somewhat, yes.
Well, that was in 18, perhaps starting in 17.
He had to work with craft unions.
But what he did was to formed shop councils, plant councils,
of the craft unions so that there would be a centralized control there.
And it was so effective that they quickly organized almost the entire packinghouse industry, 200,000 workers, and got contracts.
Unfortunately, after the war,
Foster was no longer in it because he went next into steel and other things.
But unfortunately, after the war came a violent attack on all labor by the employers, by the big interests.
The unions were beaten down.
They lost half their membership in the next few years.
But you know, I think you're familiar with that.
Did you cover the maritime strike of 1920-21?
Well, it continued through the first half of the 20s, this destruction of the unions.
Even the mighty coal miners' union was on its last legs by 27.
Though it rose again, it came back in a big way a few years later.
You said you became or was employed with the Daily Worker when it was first founded in 1924.
And how long did you stay with the paper?
Well, I was there less than a year.
Then I went to, it became, my wife and I,
took over the New York office of a trade union news agency called the Federated Press.
It lasted about 20 years, though I was only with it there for several years.
And that was owned by, organized like the Associated Press on a cooperative basis.
And there are about 100 labor papers, including a few socialist and communist papers among them, but most of them trade union papers.
And that gave me the opportunity to travel widely and covering big struggles.
For instance, I'm now writing about a chapter on a
you may not have heard of it, the Battle of Blair Mountain in West Virginia.
It was the biggest arms struggle between labor and trade unionists and gun thugs in the country's history.
Far bigger than anything else that's ever happened in this country.
What union was?
United Mine Workers.
Thousands of men on each side.
What was the date on this?
What?
When?
Twenty-one.
Starting at the end of August and continuing into September, there was a six-day gun battle with a minimum of 5,000 miners and at least that many gun thugs and state police were also with them.
The miners were winning.
There were a good many casualties among the gun thugs, not so many among the miners.
And the miners were winning when the army came in, 2,000 troops in battle gear, and the men didn't attempt to fight the troops.
As Mother Jones said to me, she was down there, the troops are the reserve gunmen for the coal operators.
President Harding was President then.
What were some other labor incidents that you covered?
Well, there was a succession of mine struggles.
A few months later, there was a, let's see, about three months later, I was in Kansas for about five weeks.
The coal fields there, a big strike.
The president and vice president were jailed altogether for 18 months, and the miners struck to free them.
Then the next year, I spent three months in Pennsylvania.
There was a five-month national strike of the miners, the longest national strike they ever had.
And I spent three months in it.
That was quite exciting.
After you helped form this Labor Federated Press, how long was it until you went back to the Daily Worker?
Well, I didn't go back until 1936.
Until 1936.
Yes.
Before this time, had you ever covered the
waterfront areas as a journalist or as a reporter?
Yes, but not consistently.
Just occasional stories.
Because there wasn't very much, there was activity, some activity among the longshoremen, but the struggle of the seamen in the big way didn't begin
until the formation of the Marine Workers Industrial Union, which was, in a way, the mother of the National Maritime Union.
I suppose you know about that.
Right.
Did you personally know Roy Hudson?
Yes, I knew Roy Hudson, yes.
He died, as you know.
The last month, yes.
Yeah.
Did Esther Palazzi give you
the latest issue of that paper, yes.
She certainly did, yes.
Yes.
Well, that's quite informative in that.
In 1936, you were given the waterfront as your territory, as a reporter for that?
No, not fully.
Just occasionally.
I wasn't the main correspondent of the waterfront.
I should say 1940, but I was in touch with it, a fairly close touch.
I spent a good deal of time then in the steel drive, the organizing of the steel union and other things, yes.
Would you like to elaborate more about the Steel Organizers Committee?
I suppose you know the story of the CIO.
Yeah.
It was first a committee for industrial organizations.
Then it became, in 1938, the name was changed to Congress of Industrial Organizations.
You see, first it was a committee because it was a committee set up by...
I believe, eight different unions.
And then it started to encourage drives in many industries.
The biggest one was in steel.
John L. Lewis played a great historical role in that.
His role historically was very bad in the 20s.
I suppose you know about that.
He was reactionary.
Under his leadership, the union fell to pieces.
But he made a remarkable change.
His personality didn't change, but his tactics changed.
As he said to me, I interviewed him
the beginning of January 36, I asked him something like this.
I said, the United Mine Workers is now at the peak of its strength.
It's never been so strong as today.
Why are you going into this larger program?
And he said in his booming voice,
My motives are not entirely altruistic, he said.
Then he explained that the miners' union could not survive if it stood alone.
He said the same interests are behind steel and some other industries as are behind the steel industry.
employers of the coal miners.
So it was necessary to get a very broad front of strong unions.
And he showed real statesmanship.
He realized that the left, particularly the communists, had great influence, had much influence,
Their organization in steel was not big, but their men were trusted.
Their representatives were trusted.
And he didn't himself take direct charge of the drive.
He entrusted it in the hands of Philip Murray, vice president of the miners' union.
But he set the overall policy.
They put a total of about 60 members of the Communist Party on the payroll.
Not a high payroll, rather low, but enough to live on with necessary expenses.
They weren't the only organizers, but I would say there were
If not the core of the organizing drive, they were the most important part of it.
And they did the job.
They organized the steel industry.
It was necessary to have a strike in 1937 then.
U.S. Steel, you see, signed up in March 1937.
But the Bethlehem and Immense Steel Republic and others held out, and a strike was called against them, which lasted several months.
It was not won officially, but it was such a demonstration of solidarity that the company signed up.

soon after the one after the other and the major plants with the exception I think perhaps of National Steel and a few others were were unionized I made my headquarters then in Pittsburgh during that drive and radiated out from there
Well, let me ask you this.
You stated earlier that in the 1920s the organized labor movement declined.
Why do you think it came up again?
What were the reasons why labor expanded in the 30s, in your opinion?
Well, there are a number of reasons.
One was that the big employers were very greedy, and they beat workers down, their working class down, and the workers had all they could take, and all that was needed was good leadership to advance.
Now, this leadership had begun even before the CIO drive, here and there, in a number of places.
There were a number of union groups that started winning strikes, and a big role was played by a number of left unions
such as the Marine Works Industrial Union, which were in the main led by communists.
I would give them a great deal of credit in this.
And as a matter of fact, before Lewis acted, a young communist steel worker, Gus Hall, you know the name,
He led a big delegation of steel workers.
He was a steel worker himself, to Washington to see Lewis.
And they told him that he would get the fullest support if he would put the resources of the United Mine Workers behind a steel drive.
Lewis did it.
He might have done it anyhow, but I think that that was probably the spark plug that started it.
Do you feel there were any other Hull himself became in charge of the drive at a rather important town called Warren, Ohio, near Youngstown, where there was a big Republic Steel plant.
besides this new leadership, do you think there are any other reasons why labor expanded in the thirties?
Do you think Roosevelt?
Yes, definitely yes.
The political atmosphere was much better for it.
You see, Roosevelt
started out very cautiously.
He himself developed a lot during the first years of his administration.
But in his NRA, National Recovery Administration, most of it was not good.
It was sort of giving a charter to
to the monopolies to take control.
But there was one little clause headed under the title 7A that workers had the right to organize, and that must be recognized.
Now Lewis again showed statesmanship of that in 1933.
His union was
almost at the bottom.
And his chief economist, Jet Lauch, he's forgotten now, but he was once rather important, told me that Lewis bet his last quarter of a million dollars in the treasury on an organizing drive then.
And he set organizers all through the coal fields.
telling them, the government is behind you.
He somewhat exaggerated that.
But it was very effective.
The workers were just looking for leadership, you see.
They were in terrible condition.
The misery in the coal fields was extremely acute.
And they swarmed into the unions.
And the United Minebrookers shot up quickly.
Just before that, you see, there had been a left-wing miners' union called the National Miners' Union, also NMU.
But when the United Miner Workers was hardly functioning at all, they conducted one very big strike and some smaller ones.
They dissolved and went back into the United Mine Workers Union and threw their progressive outlook into the locals.
And that went along with Lewis's drive, his quarter of a million dollar gamble, which paid off wonderfully well.
And that's when I was so successful that I said to him, your union is now at the peak of its strength.
But he said he was afraid it wouldn't last unless they organized the other unions.
The leadership plays a great part there.
When workers are practical, they'll fight if they see a good chance of winning.
And they were desperate, you see.
In 1936 you were associated with the Daily Worker?
Well, at first I gave all my time to the Sunday Worker, which had just been started.
But after that I worked forafter a few months I was on general assignment for the Daily.
but concentrating mainly on labor.
When was the first time that you began to associate with the seamen in the 1930s?
You said you first went to the steel, covered the steel strikes.
I did occasional assignments, you see, there.
And I had friends among the seamen.
So I kept, in the personal way, I kept in touch with it, yes.
I knew what was going on.
For instance, I knew some of the leaders of the Marine Works Industrial Union very well.
There were some very good men there.
Harry Hines, Al Lannan,
Roy I didn't know quite as intimately, but I knew him and saw him from time to time, and others.
They worked on almost an empty stomachs at the early days.
It started, I think,
One of the articles on Roy in Esser's paper, little paper, tells about it.
First was organized a social club.
That was organized by communists, and women played quite a part in that.
But that became the basis of, rather soon, of the Marine Workers Industrial Union,
which became an effective union of thousands of members.
Not as big as the NMU itself became, but a very significant union.
When did you begin to cover the waterfront in more detail?
Well, I began giving a large, not all my time, but I should say a large part of my time to it.
It was part of my beat.
I would say in 1940 there.
Did you cover any of the earlier strikes of the NMU in 36 and 37 or the tankers?
Well, I wrote some stories, but other people were doing more work there than I did.
But I knew about it, you know, and I was in on it.
Why was the Daily Worker so interested in the National Maritime Union?
What was it interested in?
Why did the Daily Worker give the National Maritime Union so much space?
Well, the Daily Worker is devoted to worker struggles, you see.
And it's a New York paper.
It's national also.
But maritime is the biggest and most important industry in New York.
It's heavy industry.
It's big industry, you see.
And so they couldn't escape it to do their job.
By 1940, then, you were covering the National Maritime Union in the seafront area.
What's that?
When was the first time that you met Joe Curran?
I don't remember.
I'd met him earlier, but I didn't have much to do with him.
I saw him frequently, though, after 1940.
What were your impressions of him as a person?
Or what are your impressions of him as a person?
I was sort of open-minded about him.
He didn't overwhelm me at all.
And he was the president of the union, so I accepted that, or you might say supported him.
But I didn't see him as a thinker, especially.
Not that he wasn't stupid, but he was not creative, I would say.
He wasn't a man to work out tactics.
And I didn't sense any great commitment on his part to a cause like, to the cause of the working class.
I didn't realize the real roughness of the man though at the time, which came out later, you see.
When was the first time that you met Blackie Myers?
Oh, I met Blackie.
I really don't know.
Probably in 36.
I'm pretty sure I met him in 36.
Curiously, Blackie and I were in the same strike in 1923, though I didn't know him then.
It's a chapter that I haven't written yet in my second volume.
San Pedro, which is the port of Los Angeles, the IWW...
carried out a strike, shut down the port, 99 ships tied up, shut down the port for about five weeks.
And a complete tie-up.
It was suppressed with police violence.
But Blackie was there as a young seaman, almost a kid.
He told me since.
But you see, there was...
There were 3,500 seamen and longshoremen there, striking.
Blackie was in that crowd.
So we had those memories together.
What were your personal impressions of Blackie Myers later, once he died?
became an official of the National American Archive?
Well, Blackie was extremely effective.
He had wonderful appeal, you know.
He had charm.
He was an excellent speaker.
He had quite a big role, I'd say.
After the seamen in 36 began their
movement to form the National Maritime Union, how popular did their cause become in the New York City area?
How popular did their cause become?
Well, it's often been said that the seamen's union
this would go back to the Marine Works Industrial Union, was not just formed by seamen, but it was formed also with the help of shoreside sympathizers.
They got a lot of help, particularly in the Chelsea area, which is the west side along the docks there.
There were a lot of good people there.
labor-conscious people who came down with literature, invited seamen into their homes, talked unionism to them there.
But I couldn't answer as to how popular it was in the city.
That's really too broad a question.
Yes.
Well, who were some of the groups then?
They got a lot of help from some very good people, though.
Well, particularly Congressman Mark Antonio, you may have heard of him.
Yes.
Yes.
He went right to the front for him, did a lot, gave him a lot of help.
And LaGuardia, first a congressman, and eventually mayor, was friendly.
LaGuardia.
How was, what was the...
During this time period from 1936 until 1940, how did the press handle the National Maritime Union?
Well, the press generally wasmost of them were anti-Union.
They were very cold about it.
There were some exceptions.
See, I think the post at that time, it had a much better ownership and management as today.
Today it's led by, it's owned by a reactionary Australian named Murdoch.
